intro: Paepalanthus parvicephalus var. wurdackii, commonly known as the dwarf puya, is a species of flowering plant native to the Andean region of South America. It belongs to the family Xanthorrhoeaceae and is characterized by its rosette-forming habit and striking, spikelike inflorescences. The plant produces small, colorful flowers that are typically arranged in dense clusters, which are pollinated by insects. It is a perennial plant that thrives in high-altitude environments with cool, moist conditions. Due to its ornamental value and ecological significance, it is often cultivated in botanical gardens and conservation programs.
